Literature Review: Induced pluripotent stem cells (iPSCs) have revolutionized the field of disease biology by providing a powerful tool for modeling human diseases in vitro. Since their discovery by Takahashi and Yamanaka in 2006, iPSCs have been derived from various somatic cell types through the introduction of specific transcription factors, offering an unprecedented opportunity to study disease mechanisms in a patient-specific manner (Takahashi et al., 2006). This breakthrough has circumvented many of the ethical and practical limitations associated with embryonic stem cells and has opened new avenues for understanding the genetic and molecular underpinnings of human diseases. One of the most significant advantages of iPSCs is their ability to differentiate into virtually any cell type, enabling researchers to study disease phenotypes in the context of specific tissues and organs. This capability has been particularly valuable in the study of complex diseases that are difficult to model in animals or immortalized cell lines. For instance, iPSCs have been used to model neurodegenerative diseases such as Parkinson's and Alzheimer's, providing insights into the cellular and molecular mechanisms underlying these conditions (Dimos et al., 2008; Israel et al., 2012). In the field of cardiology, iPSC-derived cardiomyocytes have been employed to study inherited cardiac arrhythmias and cardiomyopathies, offering a platform for drug screening and the development of personalized therapies (Moretti et al., 2010; Itzhaki et al., 2011). Similarly, iPSCs have been instrumental in advancing our understanding of pulmonary diseases, such as cystic fibrosis, by enabling the generation of patient-specific airway epithelial cells for functional studies (Wong et al., 2012). The musculoskeletal system has also benefited from iPSC technology, with studies demonstrating the potential of iPSC-derived mesenchymal stem cells for bone and cartilage regeneration (Lian et al., 2010). Despite these advancements, the use of iPSCs in disease modeling is not without challenges. One of the primary concerns is the variability in differentiation efficiency and functional maturity of iPSC-derived cells, which can affect the reproducibility and reliability of experimental results (Hu et al., 2010). Additionally, the epigenetic memory of iPSCs, which reflects the tissue of origin, can influence their differentiation potential and disease modeling capabilities (Kim et al., 2010). To address these limitations, researchers have developed iPSC-derived organoid models, which recapitulate the three-dimensional architecture and cellular complexity of human tissues. Organoids have been successfully generated for various organs, including the brain, kidney, and intestine, and have been used to study a wide range of diseases, from cancer to infectious diseases (Lancaster et al., 2013; Sato et al., 2009). These models offer a more physiologically relevant system for studying disease mechanisms and testing therapeutic interventions. In conclusion, iPSCs have emerged as a versatile and invaluable tool in disease biology, providing insights into the genetic and molecular basis of human diseases and offering new opportunities for drug discovery and personalized medicine. As the field continues to evolve, the integration of iPSC technology with advanced genomic and bioengineering approaches holds great promise for advancing our understanding of human diseases and developing more effective treatments.
